div.head: 6.7.1882 Donnerstag
div.p: Choir expedition. We started for Portsmouth by the 8.57 train. At Woking we had to change. We got to Portsmouth at about 1 o’clock and immediately went on board. It was raining hard all the time we were on the boat and from time to time we shipped some heavy seas; We saw the „Victory“, the frigate Nelson was killed on, in Portsmouth harbour. As soon as we got to Ryde we went to the station and went to Shanklyn. At Shanklyn we immediately took a ’buss and drove to the Chine Hotel where we unpacked our hampers and had dinner as it was too wet to picnic on the beach. After dinner we went down to the beach and up the cliffs to the Chine which is very beautiful; there is a high cascade and on each side of this cascade are huge rocks overgrown with green. When we got down on to the beach again we were attacked by a photographer who would insist upon photographing us; the group was pretty good and I ordered two copies. After being photographed we bathed. The sea was rather rough and we were frightfully knocked about; after my bath I had some trouble in getting the sand out of my feet. After this we immediately had tea; then I went down town and got some photographs and by this time it was so late that we nearly missed the train, especially as the coachman suddenly stopped and asked whether Mortimer mi. was inside the carriage. At the station we bought a large basket of strawberries for 3 shillings. On our way back we saw a great many soldiers at all the stations we passed evidently going to the war. At London we got the Evening Standard which had nothing but that a Rising was expected in Ireland, and that the English ships at Alexandria were being cleared for action, while the French government had ordered its ships to withdraw. We got home at about half past eleven.

p.note: Auf einer Seite sind zwei Fotografien eingeklebt. Die erste ist beschriftet mit „Shanklin beach“, die zweite mit „Shanklin Chine“.
